nodes.text: Conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis of public investments is fundamentally broken because cost and benefit estimates are highly inaccurate and systematically biased, causing misleading guidance for resource allocation

Method: assembled the largest dataset of its kind with 2,062 public investment projects (1927-2013) across eight investment types and 104 countries; measured cost overrun as actual/estimated cost and benefit overrun as actual/estimated benefit (first-year proxy)

Result: cost estimates are highly inaccurate and biased upward on average, with weighted average cost overrun about 1.39 to 1.43 (i.e., 39 to 43 percent higher actual costs); extreme skewness and fat right tail

Result: benefit estimates are inaccurate and biased downward on average (benefit shortfalls), weighted average benefit overrun about 0.94 (6 percent shortfall) with variation by investment type and fat left tail

Result: cost underestimates and benefit overestimates compound rather than cancel, so the average project suffers a 'double whammy' making benefit-cost ratios overestimated by roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on project type
Conclusion: Biased cost-benefit estimates lead to systematic resource misallocation, including initiation of projects with negative net benefits and potential long-term damage to national economies

Evidence: statistical tests strongly reject accuracy and symmetry around one for both cost and benefit overruns (Wilcoxon p<0.0001 for costs, p<0.001 for benefits) and show extreme skewness and kurtosis for cost overruns (skewness 23.2, kurtosis 724.1) and fat tails for benefits (kurtosis 6.5)

Evidence: Table 1 project-type results show average cost overruns from 1.24 for roads to 1.96 for dams and benefit shortfalls large for BRT and rail; only 327 projects had data for both cost and benefit overruns but tests replicated for that subsample

Limitation: data availability and selection/survival bias likely make sample conservative (better-performing projects overrepresented); only first-year benefits used as proxy because lifecycle data are rarely available

Claim: results are robust across conventional and Bayesian analyses and across time, geography, and project types; pattern of underestimating costs and overestimating benefits appears universal in the sample

Claim: behavioral mechanisms, not external uncertainties alone, explain systematic bias; root causes include optimism bias, planning fallacy, overconfidence, and strategic misrepresentation rather than geology or price shocks themselves

Claim: observable causes like scope changes, complexity, geology and delays are intermediate manifestations of underlying planner and stakeholder misjudgments and therefore diagnosing root behavioral causes is necessary to solve bias

Method / Remedy: reference class forecasting and taking the outside view uses empirical distributional data from past projects to mathematically de-bias forecasts; evidence of successful implementations exists (UK, Denmark, evaluations)

Claim / Recommendation: four institutional reforms are required to fix cost-benefit analysis: systematic de-biasing of forecasts, skin-in-the-game for forecasters, independent audits, and adapting cost-benefit practice to democratic, non-technocratic decision processes

Evidence / Example: legal and market accountability developments (lawsuits, criminal charges, mandating RCF in some countries) and independent evaluations demonstrate that incentives, audits, and reference class methods can produce more realistic forecasts

Conclusion: unless cost-benefit forecasts are explicitly de-biased and institutional incentives and auditing reformed, cost-benefit analysis will continue to mislead policy and be worse than worthless for resource allocation
